unnormalised: **Navigating the Chaos: Office Scheduling, Indian Style**
normalised: **Navigating the Chaos: Office Scheduling, Indian Style**

unnormalised: Boss just called a "urgent" meeting, again? Welcome to the delightful world of office scheduling in India! Forget those fancy apps promising seamless coordination. Here, things are a little… more fluid. We operate on IST (Indian Stretchable Time), so that 9:00 AM call might actually start closer to 9:30 AM. And don't even get me started on "ASAP" - that could mean anything from today to next week, depending on who you ask! My personal best was a request to "prepone" a presentation originally scheduled for 15/12/2024, to...the 14th? Logically incomprehensible, but you just nod and smile.
normalised: Boss just called an "urgent" meeting, again? Welcome to the delightful world of office scheduling in India! Forget those fancy apps promising seamless coordination. Here, things are a little… more fluid. We operate on I-S-T (Indian Stretchable Time), so that nine zero zero A-M call might actually start closer to nine thirty A-M. And don't even get me started on "A-S-A-P" - that could mean anything from today to next week, depending on who you ask! My personal best was a request to "prepone" a presentation originally scheduled for fifteenth December two thousand and twenty four, to...the fourteenth? Logically incomprehensible, but you just nod and smile.

unnormalised: Then there's the calendar clash conundrum. Trying to book a meeting room for a presentation on 20/11? Good luck! It’s either already booked for the next 3 months, or mysteriously unavailable without explanation. And if by some miracle you do manage to snag a slot, expect at least 3 people to be running late, stuck in traffic or "held up" with another meeting that "suddenly came up." Prepare for a lot of, "Sir, only 5 mins more, please."

unnormalised: Don't forget the festival season! During Diwali, from say 28/10 to 05/11, productivity dips faster than the stock market on a bad day. Officially, you might have 2 days off, but realistically, expect half the office to be on "unofficial leave". Trying to finalize that report before the holidays? Prepone that expectation to sometime next year!

unnormalised: The art of scheduling also involves understanding regional holidays. Good Friday falls on 29/03. If you are in Kerala, you might get a holiday. But if in Delhi, work continues as usual. Negotiating with colleagues across India requires knowing their local festivities like Pongal on 15/01 in Tamil Nadu.

But if in Delhi, work continues as usual. Negotiating with colleagues across India requires knowing their local festivities like Pongal on fifteenth January in Tamil Nadu.

unnormalised: Despite the chaos and occasional frustration, there's a certain charm to the Indian way of scheduling. It's a reminder that sometimes, the best-laid plans are meant to be… well, slightly adjusted. So, embrace the flexible deadlines, the "urgent" requests, and the inevitable calendar clashes. Just remember to factor in a healthy dose of chai breaks and a whole lot of patience. After all, in India, time is a suggestion, not a rule.
